title-group.article-title: Dynamics of indigenous bacterial communities associated with crude oil degradation in soil microcosms during nutrient-enhanced bioremediation

abstract.p: Bacterial population dynamics were examined during bioremediation of an African soil contaminated with Arabian light crude oil and nutrient enrichment (biostimulation). Polymerase chain reaction followed by denaturing gradient gel electrophoresis (DGGE) were used to generate bacterial community fingerprints of the different treatments employing the 16S ribosomal ribonucleic acid (rRNA) gene as molecular marker. The DGGE patterns of the nutrient-amended soils indicated the presence of distinguishable bands corresponding to the oil-contaminated–nutrient-enriched soils, which were not present in the oil-contaminated and pristine control soils. Further characterization of the dominant DGGE bands after excision, reamplification and sequencing revealed that Corynebacterium spp., Dietzia spp., Rhodococcus erythropolis sp., Nocardioides sp., Low G+C (guanine plus cytosine) Gram positive bacterial clones and several uncultured bacterial clones were the dominant bacterial groups after biostimulation. Prominent Corynebacterium sp. IC10 sequence was detected across all nutrient-amended soils but not in oil-contaminated control soil. Total heterotrophic and hydrocarbon utilizing bacterial counts increased significantly in the nutrient-amended soils 2 weeks post contamination whereas oil-contaminated and pristine control soils remained fairly stable throughout the experimental period. Gas chromatographic analysis of residual hydrocarbons in biostimulated soils showed marked attenuation of contaminants starting from the second to the sixth week after contamination whereas no significant reduction in hydrocarbon peaks were seen in the oil-contaminated control soil throughout the 6-week experimental period. Results obtained indicated that nutrient amendment of oil-contaminated soil selected and enriched the bacterial communities mainly of the Actinobacteria phylogenetic group capable of surviving in toxic contamination with concomitant biodegradation of the hydrocarbons. The present study therefore demonstrated that the soil investigated harbours hydrocarbon-degrading bacterial populations which can be biostimulated to achieve effective bioremediation of oil-contaminated soil.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Crude oil pollution is considered as one of the major environmental problems faced by oil-producing countries of the world including Nigeria (Ayotamuno et al., 2006; Chikere, 2010; Chikere and Chijioke-Osuji, 2006; Chikere et al., 2008, 2009a, b). Details of actual contamination of the terrestrial ecosystem by oil in Nigeria are difficult to quantify because most oil spillages are due to anthropogenic causes such as pipeline vandalism (Nweke and Okpokwasili, 2004). Crude oil-contaminated land is costly to remediate using physicochemical methods; for example in the USA the cost is expected to exceed US$1 trillion per year (Stroud et al., 2007).

Bioremediation has been established as a cost-effective strategy for the remediation of petroleum hydrocarbon pollutants in the soil. The process is mainly mediated by micro-organisms which are ubiquitous in the soil. There is a myriad of literature on the subject of oil degradation by bacteria and it is now generally accepted that no single species of bacteria will completely degrade any particular oil (Cappello et al., 2007; Hamamura et al., 2006; Higashioka et al., 2009; Macnaughton et al., 1999; Mahmoud et al., 2009; Maila et al., 2006; Montiel et al., 2009; Quatrini et al., 2008; Rodrigues et al., 2009; Ruberto et al., 2009; Wolicka et al., 2009). The degradation of crude oil in the soil involves a consortium of bacteria, thus for this reason, the assessment of soil microbial community structure (the relative abundance of populations within the community) and function (the key processes driven by such populations in the polluted soil) through the analysis of DNA molecules extracted from the soil matrices are of paramount importance to better understand the biochemical changes that occur during crude oil degradation (Malik et al., 2008; Morales and Holben, 2011; Rajendhran and Gunasekaran, 2011; Simon and Daniel, 2011; Van Elsas et al., 2007). Changes in hydrocarbon content in soils during bioremediation resulted in characteristic shifts in microbial populations and the abundance of hydrocarbon-utilizing bacteria (Hamamura et al., 2006; Kaplan and Kitts, 2004; Lal et al., 2010; Maila et al., 2006; Ruberto et al., 2009).

The objectives of this study were to determine whether oil contamination alone enriches specific bacterial populations and to monitor the microbial community after biostimulation by nutrient amendment to oil-contaminated soil. The population dynamics of indigenous bacterial communities responding to crude oil pollution in a soil of sandy clay texture was investigated after biostimulation with organic and inorganic nutrient sources. Culture-dependent and independent techniques were used to monitor the changes in the bacterial dynamics and structure over time.

sec.title: Sampling site and soil properties
sec.p: The soil used for the study was collected from a site with no history of previous oil contamination, located at the University of Pretoria experimental farm, Republic of South Africa. The portion of soil taken for the experiment had never been cultivated at the time of the investigation. The soil texture was sandy clay (85% sand, 10% clay and 5% silt). The characteristics of the fresh soil used for the study are shown in Table 1. The values presented represent the mean of three sub-samples analysed for each parameter.

caption.p: Physicochemical characteristics of fresh soil used in the study

sec.title: Experimental design
sec.p: Soil was collected from the surface horizon (A horizon) and divided into fifteen 5 L pots each containing 4 kg of soil. The height of the pot was 24 cm with five openings at the base to prevent water logging. The soil sample occupied approximately half the volume of the pot leaving enough head space. A picture of the pot is shown in Figure 1. The experiments were carried out in triplicate to represent five different treatment regimens namely NPK (nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium)-amended soil (PN), calcium ammonium nitrate-amended soil (PU), poultry droppings (chicken manure)-amended soil (PP), oil-contaminated control (OC) and pristine control (PC). All treatments except PC were contaminated with 160 mL of Arabian light crude oil.

caption.p: The pot used in the experiment.

sec.p: The oil-contaminated soil samples were thoroughly mixed with a hand trowel sanitized with 70% ethanol. For the nutrient-amended soils, 25 g of NPK, calcium ammonium nitrate or poultry droppings was dissolved in 200 mL sterile distilled water and mixed with the contaminated soil to distribute the crude oil and nutrients through the soil particles and also to enhance aeration. Microcosms were kept at room temperature in a greenhouse; nutrient-treated soils were regularly watered weekly with 200 mL sterile distilled water to substitute for evaporated water and also mixed every other day for aeration.

The oil-contaminated and pristine controls (OC and PC) were left undisturbed throughout the 6-week experimental period and as expected lost water rapidly. Addition of water in the nutrient-amended treatments maintained soil moisture at the same level as statistical analysis using one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) and Tukey’s multiple comparison test showed that the moisture contents in PN, PU and PP were not significant at p < 0.05 when compared with each other whereas they were significant at p < 0.05 when compared individually with OC and PC, respectively. The microcosms were sampled at days 0, 7, 14, 21, 28, 35 and 42.

Three sub-samples representing one from individual microcosm were collected from each treatment and bulked to obtain a composite sample as follows: (1) PN soil; (2) PU soil; (3) PP soil; (4) OC soil; and (5) PC soil.

sec.title: Enumeration of total heterotrophic bacterial and hydrocarbon utilizing bacterial counts
sec.p: From a composite sample of each treatment, 1 g of soil was homogenized in 9 mL 0.85% NaCl using a Heindolph vortexing machine (Germany). Decimal dilutions (10-fold) of the suspensions were plated out on Plate Count Agar (Merck, Germany) and incubated at 30°C for 24 hours for the total heterotrophic bacterial (THB) counts. For hydrocarbon utilizing bacterial (HUB) counts, appropriate dilutions of soil suspensions were plated out on Bushnell–Haas agar (Sigma-Aldrich, USA). Hydrocarbons were supplied through the vapour phase to putative hydrocarbon utilizers by placing sterile Whatman No.1 filter papers impregnated with 5 mL Arabian light crude oil on the lids of the inverted plates. Plates were incubated at 30°C for 7 days.

sec.title: Gas chromatographic analysis
sec.p: Residual hydrocarbons were extracted from PN, PU, PP and OC soils (5 g each) weekly starting from day zero with 40 μL of n-pentane (HPLC grade) grade) by sonicating the sample 5 min at each extraction for three times. The pentane extract was centrifuged at 3000g for 5 min. The three organic phases were dried over Na2SO4, pooled together and adjusted to 150 μL after the additionof 32 μL of Cumene (Isopropyl benzene) was added as internal standard. The analysis was carried out using a Varian 1440 GC-FID (California, USA). A DB-1 column was used with the following dimensions: 30 m × 0.2 mm; 0.25 μm film thickness; 0.32 i.d. Helium was the carrier gas at a flow rate of 1 mL min−1. Analyses were carried out in split injection mode using a split ratio 5 : 1. The injection port was set at 250°C. The oven temperature was programmed from 40°C for 10 min, then 20°C min−1 to 330°C, holding this temperature for 10 min.

sec.title: Soil DNA extraction
sec.p: Total microbial community DNA from microcosms corresponding to the five treatments was extracted from 0.25 g of soil using the Zymo Research Soil Microbe DNA kit (Inqaba Biotech, South Africa) and the Bio 101 FP-120 FastPrep cell disruptor (Qbiogene, Inc. Canada). The machine was set at a speed of 5.0 m s−1 for 45 s. Extracted DNA samples were quantified using the NanoDrop ND-1000 spectrophotometer (USA) before the 16S rRNA gene fragments were amplified by polymerase chain reaction (PCR). The concentration of DNA used for PCR ranged from 22 to 51 ng μL−1.

sec.title: Polymerase chain reaction
sec.p: Amplification of the template DNA was performed using 2 μL volume of the extracted DNA with BIO RAD MJ Mini thermal cycler (Mexico). The 50 μL PCR mixture contained 5 μL deoxy nucleoside triphosphates (dNTPs) mixture (2.5 μmol L−1) (Promega, USA), 5 μL of 5× Green Go Taq Flexi buffer (Promega), 3.5 μL of 25 mmol L−1 MgCl2 (Promega), 2 μL each of 10 pmol of both forward (primer M) and reverse (primer K) primers pA8f-GC (5′-CGC-CCG-CCG-CGC-GCG-GCG-GCG-GGC-GGG-GCG-GGG-GCA-GGG-GAG-AGT-TTG-ATC-CTG-GCT-CAG-3′) and KPRUN518r (5′-ATTACCGCGGCTGCTGG-3′) (Maila et al., 2006), 0.25 μL of 5 U μL−1 hot start Go Taq DNA polymerase, 2.5 μL−1 of 20 mg mL−1 of bovine serum albumin and 27.75 μL of sterile water. A reaction tube without template DNA was included as negative control. The PCR programme was as follows: denaturing step at 95°C for 3 min, followed by 33 cycles at 95°C for 30 s, annealing for 30 s at 55°C and extension at 72°C for 1 min, followed by a final extension at 72°C for 7 min and then held at 4°C. Amplified DNA was examined by electrophoresis in 1.4% agarose gel with 2 μL aliquots of PCR products in 1× Tris-acetate-EDTA buffer.

sec.title: Denaturing gradient gel electrophoresis
sec.p: PCR products were subjected to denaturing gradient gel electrophoresis (DGGE) according to the method described by Muyzer et al. (1993) using BioRad Dcode Multi Mutation Detection System. Ten microlitres containing 250 ng of the various 16 S rRNA-amplified gene fragments were loaded per lane onto 25–55% denaturing gradient gel. Gel was run at 70 V for 17 h at a constant temperature of 60°C. Selected bands were picked under blue light from DGGE gel using a sterile micropipette tip. Each band was assigned a number for sequence analysis. The gel blocks were placed in 30 μL sterile distilled water and allowed to stand overnight. DNA fragments from bands were then subjected to PCR as described above.

sec.title: Sequencing
sec.p: The PCR products of excised bands were sequenced with the K primer using an ABI 3130XL genetic analyser (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, CA) incorporating the ABI Big Dye Terminator Cycle Sequencing kit version 3.1 (Applied Biosystems). Sequencing was performed by Inqaba Biotechnical Industries Pty. Ltd, South Africa. Electropherograms of the sequences generated were inspected with Finch TV software (Geospiza). Sequence identification was performed using the BLAST-N facility of the National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI).

sec.title: Bacterial counts
sec.p: The trends in the culturable bacterial counts for the 6 weeks period are shown in Figures 2 and 3. It was observed that the nutrient-amended pots PN, PU, PP peaked in the THB counts by day 21. These remained fairly stable until day 35 after which the counts started decreasing. The THB counts for the OC increased slightly by day 7, decreased by day 21, increased slightly and remained stable between days 28 and 35. After this period, the counts started decreasing. The THB for PC remained fairly stable from day zero till day 42 (Figures 1 and 2).

Total culturable hydrocarbon utilizing bacterial counts during bioremediation. PN, NPK-amended soil; PU, calcium ammonium nitrate-amended soil; PP, poultry droppings (chicken manure)-amended soil; OC, oil-contaminated control; PC, pristine control.

sec.p: The HUB counts for the nutrient-amended pots peaked by day 14 for PN (NPK-amended soil) and PP (poultry droppings/chicken manure-amended soil) while PU (calcium ammonium nitrate-amended soil) peaked by day 21.

The PN treatment showed the greatest decrease of the pollutants by day 14 followed by PU and PP by day 21 respectively (Figure 4). It was observed that almost all the hydrocarbons in the amended soils were degraded 3 weeks after oil contamination. By day 42 the heights of the hydrocarbon peaks were all reduced in the nutrient-amended soils in this order, PN > PU > PP whereas no noticeable decrease was observed in the oil-contaminated control (OC). Reduction in heights of hydrocarbons as displayed in chromatograms is used qualitatively to score the progress of hydrocarbon degradation (Atlas and Philp, 2005; Challian et al., 2004; Leahy and Colwell, 1990; Stroud et al., 2007). Sigmoid curves (Figure 5(a) to (c)) were also generated from the degradation rates of the hydrocarbons in the biostimulated treatments. Degradation was determined as percentage of degraded hydrocarbon measured from the area under the peaks of the chromatograms relative to the amount of hydrocarbon of the corresponding abiotic control [oil-contaminated control (OC)]. The curve derived for the PN treatment (Figure 5(a)) had the best fit for the points plotted followed by PP (Figure 5(c)) and PU (Figure 5(b)), respectively. As there was no significant loss of hydrocarbons from the OC treatment, the disappearance of these hydrocarbons in the nutrient-amended treatments could be attributed to biostimulation and increased bacterial activity which resulted in biodegradation of the contaminants. This observation corroborates the findings of Quatrini et al. (2008) in a related study.

caption.p: Gas chromatograms (from the top downwards) of the oil-contaminated control days 0, 42; NPK-amended soil (PN) days 0, 14 and 42; calcium ammonium nitrate-amended soil (PU) days 0, 21 and 42; poultry droppings-amended soil (PP) days 0, 21 and 42.

Sigmoid curves showing rates of hydrocarbon degradation in the nutrient-amended soils relative to the oil-contaminated control: (a) PN, NPK-amended soil; (b) PU, calcium ammonium nitrate-amended soil; (c) PP, poultry droppings (chicken manure)-amended soil.

sec.p: Throughout the 42-day period, PN (NPK-amended soil) showed the most effective degradation of the crude oil. The bacterial counts, however, did not reflect these trends since PP (poultry droppings/chicken manure-amended soil) showed the highest counts for both THB and HUB. Poultry droppings have been shown to contain a large number of micro-organisms (Williams et al., 1999) which may have been an added inoculum to the ones already in the soil as also recorded in this study. Micro-organisms identified from the poultry litter used in the study were Pseudomonas spp., Escherichia coli, Mycobacterium spp and Salmonella spp., but sequences of these bacteria were not identified in the DGGE which possibly meant they may not have been among the dominant hydrocarbon degrading microbiota despite the increase in THB and HUB counts they caused in the PP treatment. In the same vein, Van Hamme et al. (2003) reported that the mineral salts medium used in the isolation of HUB can favour even non-degrading microbes because of traces of carbon in agar thereby overestimating their numbers and importance during bioremediation. Hamamura et al. (2006) in their study also reported the cultivation of numerous HUB from oil-contaminated soil which did not correlate with the results obtained using culture-independent molecular techniques and advised that molecular methods should be used to confirm and verify such results obtained using traditional cultivation methods. It has also been observed that fast-growing micro-organisms best adapted to particular culture conditions grow preferentially than those which are not and therefore do not accurately represent the actual microbial community composition of contaminated ecosystems during bioremediation (Malik et al., 2008). Hence culture-dependent characterization of hydrocarbon degraders from hydrocarbon-contaminated sites limits the scope of microbial diversity and the ecological importance of unculturable organisms in such environments may be undetected (Chikere, 2010; Delmont et al., 2011; Van Hamme et al., 2003).

sec.title: Molecular analysis of bacterial community dynamics
sec.p: Total community DNA extracted from all treatments yielded high molecular weight DNA. PCR products were obtained from all soil DNA samples. Hence the oil used to contaminate soil samples did not affect the quality of DNA extracted from the soil. DNA samples used for PCR and DGGE were taken from the days where appreciable reduction in hydrocarbon peaks was demonstrated in the chromatograms. Banding patterns showed that dominant DGGE bands appeared in nutrient-amended soils PN, PU, PP over time (0-42 days) and not in the pristine or oil-contaminated soil control [PCB (pristine control baseline), OCB (oil-contaminated soil control baseline), OC0 (oil- contaminated soil control day zero), OC42 (oil-contaminated soil control day 42)) (Figure 6). In PN soil, no dominant bands were observed on day zero of the experiment, but a prominent band pn1 appeared on day 14 and persisted till day 42. Bands pn2 and pn3 were also dominant by day 42 although they did not appear 2 weeks after treatment commenced. A faint band, pn4 also appeared in PN on day zero and remained the same until day 42. In PU soil, a prominent band pu1 was seen on day zero which did not appear again throughout the study period. Two additional prominent bands pu2 and pu3 appeared on day 14 and persisted throughout the experiment followed by pu4 which emerged on day 14 although not as prominent as the former. Faint bands pu5 and pu6 were also seen on days 21 and 42, respectively. A band, pp2 appeared in PP soil on day zero but became more prominent from day 14 and persisted throughout the study period. Bands pp1 and pp3 were faintly seen only on day zero and never appeared again subsequently whereas band pp4, which emerged on day 14, persisted throughout the experiment. All nutrient-amended soils showed obvious successional patterns, in which most DGGE bands emerging early in the experiment disappeared with time as others that appeared later remained relatively prominent throughout the study period (Figure 6). Conversely, no obvious changes in DGGE banding patterns were observed in the oil-contaminated control (oc0 and oc42) during the experimental period. Consequently, the populations corresponding to the prominent DGGE bands in nutrient-amended soils were ascribed to biostimulation rather than oil contamination alone.

caption.p: DGGE profiles of 16S rRNA gene fragments from pcb, pristine control; ocb, oil-contaminated control baseline; oc0, oil-contaminated control day zero; oc42, oil-contaminated control day 42 and nutrient-amended soils pn0; pn14; pn42 (NPK-amended soil days zero, 14 and 42); pu0; pu14; pu21; pu42 (calcium ammonium nitrate-amended soil days zero, 14, 21 and 42); pp0; pp14; pp28; pp42 (poultry droppings-amended soil days zero, 14, 28, 42).

sec.p: The DNA sequences of some of the prominent DGGE bands corresponding to bacterial populations selected during crude oil degradation are reported along with their closest GenBank relatives in Table 2. All the sequences obtained in the study were deposited in GenBank under accession numbers GU451069 to GU451108. Phylogenetically diverse populations related to the Actinobacteria, Chloroflexi, γ-Proteobacteria and Firmicutes were identified across the nutrient-amended soils. However the DNA sequences of bands pn1, pu2 and pp4 were detected in PN, PU and PP treatments. The sequences corresponding to these bands were 99, 100 and 96%, respectively, identical to the partial 16S rRNA gene sequence of Corynebacterium sp. IC10. All 16S rRNA sequences obtained from the nutrient-amended soils were mostly affiliated with Gram positive organisms and they clustered within the Corynebacterium–Dietzia–Nocardioides–Rhodococcus complex, members of which are known to degrade crude oil hydrocarbons (Bouchez-Naitali et al., 1999; Chaillan et al., 2003; Daly et al., 1997; Hamamura et al., 2006; Kloos et al., 2006; Larkin et al., 2005; Leahy and Colwell, 1990; Margesin et al., 2003; Philp et al., 2005; Popp et al., 2006; Quatrini et al., 2008).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In the present study, DGGE analysis of PCR-amplified 16S rRNA gene fragments from bacterial DNA were combined with culture-dependent and analytical chemistry techniques to study crude oil degradation and the dynamics of bacterial communities in a crude oil-contaminated soil over a 42-day period. Culture-dependent methods have been used by several researchers to isolate bacteria involved in the degradation of petroleum hydrocarbons (Adoki and Orugbani, 2007; Ayotamuno et al., 2006; Chaillan et al., 2004; Chikere and Chijioke-Osuji; 2006; Ebuehi et al., 2005; Maila et al., 2006; Nweke and Okpokwasili, 2004; Odokuma and Dickson, 2003; Rojas-Avelizapa et al., 2007), even though only a fraction of soil bacteria involved in biodegradation can currently be cultured in the laboratory (Heinzel et al., 2009; Malik et al., 2008; Surridge et al., 2005; Zengler, 2008). It was observed that total culturable heterotrophic and hydrocarbon utilizing bacterial counts increased in the biostimulated soils (PN, PU and PP) starting from second week to the sixth week of bioremediation period reaching the highest numbers by days 35 and 42, respectively. On the other hand, populations of both culturable heterotrophic and hydrocarbon-utilizing bacterial counts remained stable throughout the experimental period in the oil-contaminated and pristine control soils (OC and PC). Several studies have also recorded an increase in culturable heterotrophic and hydrocarbon-utilizing bacterial counts during crude oil biodegradation following biostimulation (Ayotamuno et al., 2006; Chaillan et al., 2004; Chikere and Chijioke-Osuji, 2006; Ebuehi et al., 2005; Margesin et al., 2003; Nweke and Okpokwasili, 2004; Ruberto et al., 2009; Wolicka et al., 2009). Changes in bacterial counts detected in all biostimulated soils were induced by the addition of nutrients rather than oil contamination alone. This same observation was made by Evans et al. (2004) when they investigated the impact of oil contamination and biostimulation on the diversity of indigenous bacterial communities in soil microcosms.

The most consistent pattern observed in the present study was the emergence of Corynebacterium sp. IC10-like bacteria in all nutrient-amended soils (Figure 6; bands pn1, pu2 and pp4) treated with different organic and inorganic nutrients. Wide distribution of these bacterial species in the biostimulated soils possibly indicates the importance of Corynebacterium spp. in hydrocarbon degradation. This finding is consistent with results from previous studies showing the prevalence of hydrocarbon-degrading Corynebacterium spp. in various hydrocarbon-contaminated soils using culture-dependent (Adebusoye et al., 2007; Bouchez-Naitali et al., 1999; Rahman et al., 2002) and -independent approaches (Jimenez et al., 2007). Biostimulation of the contaminated soils with aeration and nutrient amendments showed that changes in the abundance and diversity of bacterial populations occurred from the second week after treatment. Both total culturable heterotrophic and hydrocarbon-utilizing bacterial counts increased appreciably during this same period, in parallel with marked changes in the structure of the bacterial community as was shown by population fingerprinting. However, PU and PP soils showed a stable bacterial profile starting from day 14 to day 42, the last day of the experiment, unlike PN soil where population succession was observed throughout the same period. This suggests that PU and PP soils may habour specialist populations that possess alkane degradation pathways with broad hydrocarbon specificity as also observed by Hamamura et al. (2006). PU soil had sequences mainly from the Actinobacteria phylogenetic group and it is well documented that members of this group are known hydrocarbon degraders (van Beilen et al., 2007; Bell et al., 1998; Chaillan et al., 2004; Evans et al., 2004; Hamamura et al., 2006; Quatrini et al., 2008; Van Hamme et al., 2003). PP soil had sequences from both Actinobacteria and Firmicutes groups. Other studies demonstrated that these groups can degrade various hydrocarbons (Evans et al., 2004; Hamamura et al., 2006; Larkin et al., 2005; Leahy and Colwell, 1990; Popp et al., 2006). Changes in the band intensities were also detected over time in the biostimulated soils, indicating that changes in bacterial community structure were predominantly induced by nutrient addition rather than oil spiking alone since the crude oil used for contamination was applied at the same concentration of 4% in all soil microcosms. This observation was also made by Zucchi et al. (2003) and Evans et al. (2004). Other independent studies have underscored the use of biostimulation to promote the degradation of petroleum hydrocarbons (Ayotamuno et al., 2006; Balba et al., 1998; Ijah and Antai, 2003; Macnaughton et al., 1999; Nweke and Okpokwasili, 2004; Odokuma and Dickson, 2003; Okpokwasili, 2006; Ruberto et al., 2009; Williams et al., 1999; Wolicka et al., 2009) in different ecological contexts. Given the optimal conditions for microbial activity, soil micro-organisms when challenged with anthropogenic and natural sources of hydrocarbon contaminants over time adapt by selective enrichment and this concomitantly leads to the biodegradation of these compounds.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: It was concluded that bacterial population changes occurred as a result of biostimulation. Nutrient input, aeration and watering enhanced biodegradation capabilities of the autochthonous bacterial populations. Denaturing gradient gel electrophoresis of PCR –amplified 16S rRNA gene used in this study provided a rapid and efficient culture-independent approach to elucidate the bacterial diversity and community structure during bioremediation. This approach assisted in monitoring the progress of bioremediation in both semi-quantitative and qualitative ways, respectively.
